Hi David 

Thank you very much for your advice. I agree that kinetics calcu=
lated
outside the valid range of the NASA polynomial coefficients is likely=

to be prone to errors. I will try to expand the polynomial fit with
(if pr=
esent) data from the literature. 

Kind regards 

Anders

PS: You probably =
hear this often, but I would like to thank you for
making such a great piec=
e of code available to the public - and of
course also for your vast amount=
 of rapid answers on this mailing list. 

--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, D=
avid Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
> Yes, you may be able to do it.  Cant=
era does not catch every possible  
> error that can be made... But I would=
 strongly advise reviewing the  
> high temperature thermo data for the spe=
cies with fits that end at  
> 1500 K before believing the results either f=
rom equilibrium or by  
> integrating rate equations...  Extrapolating thes=
e NASA-style  
> polynomials outside the range for which they were fit can =
lead to  
> very big errors, since the polynomial may have physically unrea=
listic  
> behavior.
> 
> 
> On Jan 17, 2007, at 8:01 AM, Anders Andreasen =
wrote:
> 
> > Dear Cantera users
> >
> > I am doing some calculations using=
 the Leeds sulfur mechanism  
> > extension (cantera 1.6 through python 2.4=
 on Red Hat Enterprise  
> > Linux WS 4) including both equilibrium
> > and=
 kinetics calculations. If I try to equlibrate a gas phase  
> > solution b=
ased on the this mechanism (with included thermodynamic  
> > description) =
I get the following error
> >
> > *****************************************=
*******
> >                 Cantera Error!
> > ****************************=
********************
> > Procedure: ChemEquil
> > Error:   Specified temper=
ature ( 1971.65 K) outside valid range of  
> > 300 K to 1500 K
> >
> > Thi=
s of course expected behaviour since some of the species  
> > thermodynami=
c parameters are only given up to 1500 K.
> > However, I can still integrat=
e the rate equations (see code below -  
> > the description of the composi=
tion of the SOx gas has been left out  
> > in this mail)
> >
> > soxgas=3D=
Cantera.importPhase('SOx.cti')
> > soxgas.setTemperature(2000)
> > tnow =3D=
 0.
> > tfinal =3D self.dt
> > reactor =3D Reactor.Reactor(contents =3D sox=
, name =3D 'reactor1', energy  
> > =3D 'off')
> > reactor_net =3D Reactor.=
ReactorNet([reactor])
> > while tnow < tfinal:
> > tnow =3D reactor_net.ste=
p(tfinal)
> > reactor_net.reactors()[0].syncContents()
> >
> > In the ctml =
file all reactions are listed as being reversible.
> > I have the impressio=
n that the reverse reaction rate is calculated  
> > as the forward reactio=
n rate constant divided by the equilibrium  
> > constant i.e.k_f/K_eq.
> >=
 What puzzles me here is the fact that. while not being able to do  
> > eq=
uilibration, it is still possible to calculate the equilibrium  
> > consta=
nt (which I guess is calculated with NASA coefficients from  
> > the cti/x=
ml file)..
> >
> > I would very much appreciate any input on this topic
> >=

> > Kind regards
> >
> >
>
